classification: Ceramics; Tools, Equipment and Utilitarian Objects
creditline: Gift of funds from the Friends of the Institute
description: small, round-bodied ceramic vessel with short neck; brown mottled glaze
text: Traveling Japanese Zen monks returned to their country bearing many prized objects from Sung dynasty China, like this cha-ire or tea caddy. Small, finely crafted containers originally created to store spices and medicines, cha-ire were used by the Japanese to hold powdered tea for use in their tea ceremonies. Jars with a distinctly round shape, such as this one, were called bunrin or "apple-shaped" caddies. A previous owner of this cha-ire assigned it the poetic name "waterdrop," which he inscribed on the caddy's outer box.
title: Tea caddy (chaire)
